review_title: It has been an interesting experience working at NUS for me.
pros:
The pace of worklife is manageable and ther is plenty of training opportunities which are FOC.
Lateral transfers to other departments creates internal job opportunities for existing staff whose staff benefits will not be affected (eg. days of leave and long service awards) unlike quitting and joining a new firm outside.
cons:
The lack of central HR support in interviewing staff also pumps up the recuitment costs including a waste of interviewers' time ; it is a vicious circle, i.e No support from central HR or faculty HR in selection interviews -> wrong staff recruited -> training resources pumped in -> staff cannot perform or staff leaves -> recruit again.
Top mgt HR is unaware (or not interested in) what happens on the grounds; When issues are escalated upwards after getting no where with the Officer in charge, the senior mgt staff merely refers it back to the same Officer handling the issue!

pros: I had to enter at least 5 words for Pros.
cons: inter-departmental politics; a lot of time spent doing work to prove that you're doing work (assessments / evaluations / KPI etc); meetings for the sake of holding meetings (an indirect way to prove that work is being done...related to previous point); fear about chain of accountability -- nobody takes charge or takes risks b/c of a fear that, should something go wrong, the heat will fall on them. These issues existed within my own department as well as within OHR as well. OHR was continually evasive and failed to address the root of my grievances (they went unresolved throughout the entire course of my employment). In one instance, instead of resolving an inquiry with my directly, they began discussing my inquiry with other members of my office, which I felt was a gross violation of confidentiality and professionalism.

review_title: Management fail to warn staff upfront of the absurd probation failure rate (80%) before staff accepts the offer.
pros: Good work life balance and good working environment. Reputable institute and the name speaks for itself. Lots of eateries and benefit is not too bad.
cons: Management's expectations are really subjective and if they think you're not good enough, you won't pass your probation despite everything you do. They "boast" about the high turnover rate in the dept but there's a reason why the staff turnover rate is so high. Stick with someone for some time, you will get good results with motivated staff. Management was not upfront and honest in stating to potential staff that 80%  staff won't pass probation and will be asked to leave. I gave up a fantastic offer abroad to join the dept only to be asked to leave 6 months later.

review_title: Organizationally chaotic and still figuring out the tenure-track system
pros: Branding and self-identify as a top tier research instition
cons: Reality is that NUS has still a long way to go if it wants to be an R1 university. It still hasn't fully figured out how to assess its faculty members - and thus there is constant self-doubt and coming up with new metrics on how to assess research. The bureaucracy here is tremendous - there are lots of people left over from the old NUS (pre-NUS as a enterprise/research *insert other buzzword here* institution). Hence it talks forever to get things done. This is because there is a real tension between management by audit culture and management by neglect.  The fact of the matter is - the university has a public mandate to teach but has the ambitions of being an R1. This tension will never be resolved. Also, budgetary cuts - especially in the areas of graduate student funding and research funding - will make faculty's life constantly interesting.

review_title: World-class leadership with lackluster middle management
pros: NUS is definitely one of the best universities in the world. Its students are highly intelligent, driven, and articulate. Its resources for teaching and research are abundant. Its library is top-notch. Its global reputation is stellar.
cons: NUS may have recently slipped in the university rankings because of its mid-level administrators, who aspire to be little LKYs but lack his vision and creativity. I work in one of the teaching units, which is run by people without PhDs. Someone regularly checks on us to make sure we're in our offices when we're not in the classroom. We need to apply for personal leaves and conference funds by filing copious paperwork, which is subject to the discretion of the director. Turnover is high.

pros: Brand name which is good for your resume. Great for using as a spring board to better things.
cons: This University does not value admin staff. The support staff are better paid with less responsibilities, while the bulk of the budget goes to research and academia.  Salaries are way below benchmark.

review_title: Admin staff: good if you like stability, bad if you're looking for career growth
pros:
- good work/life balance, rarely need to do overtime work
- stable government-linked institution, so your job is secure even if you are a slightly below average performer
- friendly working environment in general
cons:
- a lot of red tape leading to lots of frustration, especially since top level management seems to oblivious about sentiments on the ground
- slow career progression, can be boring
- rude professors can really bog you down

pros:
Plenty of room for individuals to grow since CIRC's research portfolio is expanding
Opportunities to build relationships with people in academia, government offices and industry sponsors
cons: It's a fast-paced and diverse environment and one has to find the right people in the right offices to resolve issues. Otherwise things wouldn't get going.

pros: 21 days leave a year for a research fellow, of course the permit is at your "boss"'s hand, usually a professor.
cons: Usually it is a contract job, meaning temporary and not stable. And a research fellow got no bonus at all.

review_title: It is pleasant to work in NUS and I have a lot of leisure time.
pros: To do academic research, to have a lot of freedom for planning career development, and to live a pleasant life in Singapore.
cons: Salary is not very satisfactory unless you hold a very high position. Weather is hot all the year around. Life is sometimes dull.

review_title: Well funded research institution with a large cultural span
pros: HR and management is very competent and compensation is good. In my department there is not much top-down management of research, but I know that to be different elsewhere.
cons: With a lot of different cultures working together there are bound to be some tensions, especially since all the support staff is local. Also, if you are starting a research group, be aware that the students make great efforts to do their PHD's abroad.

pros: Very flexible hours and high autonomy in deciding what to do. Interesting topic with a great deal of learning taking place.
cons: Low pay with very limited value to resume unless you are gearing towards an advanced degree. Really, just work for the experience and interaction with the faculty (and the pay, of course).

review_title: very competitive environment at National University of Singapore
pros: Singapore has rich funding in carrying out frontier researches. So even when many universities around the world suffers from decrease in endowment, Singapore university remains prosperous.
cons: Stressful. Most people work really hard. School administration here is slow because decision process needs to stick to rigid bureaucracy.

review_title: a university with fastly improving research quality and reputation
pros: Well connected with universities and research institutes around the world. Well-defined US style evaluation process. Nice working and living environment.
cons: Though the research quality and reputation of the university has improved significantly over the recent years, it is still not well recognized yet.

pros: The campus is beautiful. And the life here is changlle but interested. However, sometimes you need face some tough task and conque it.
cons: The tuition fee is expensive. The lab is old. And the campus is small,which requires further expansion. Also the food is not so good.

pros: You can look up all military pay online and the changes to pay are posted up every year. Pay also changes depending where you are located with BAH or OHA.
cons: If you are concerned about pay, get your degree and try to become an officer. However, I would also say that the Army is not the best place to go if all you want to do is make money.

pros: you can work together with some very smart computer scientist. you have the chance to solve the most challenging problems
cons: sometimes, you will have to work on your own, and the work may be very very challenging and difficult. it depends on you

pros: It is convenient to train stations
cons: Ex-colleagues in the office likes to stir politics and do not work with each other. Prefers to behave in cliques and gossip behind each other's back. Human resources do not help you when things go wrong. Open your eyes wide and check the situation before you enter! All the management play politics and try to get allies. They have good salary but they are all unhappy. Climb is slow and people are childish and get jealous very easily. The worst bunch of people I have ever met while working.

pros: a relax and flexible working place with all nice colleagues. Quite stable as it is supported by singapore government. Salary paid on time
cons: all depend on your qualification and ranking. Sometimes  need to serve Professor who create trouble and demanding and not respective at all

pros: Great working environment, good learning experience. Generous support in terms of resources. Beautiful city to live in and extremely convenient.
cons: Limited opportunities and variability in terms of available work; city can get quite claustrophobic, sometimes vibes around are not good.

pros: Degree, MIT exposure, Dual Degree, With no costs, industrial practice, good friends, good professors, suitable for further education, good place for reading
cons: easy to be thought too engineering for a lot of other workers, esp in Singapore, opportunity costs and some other issues

job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros:
good place to study and work you will meet great professors and students 
you can find good labs as well
cons: too crowded since this school has accepted a lot more students than before and resources are provided enough for the new increased number of guys

review_title: A leading global university centred in Asia, influencing the future
pros: NUS will be a globally-oriented university, in the distinguished league of the world’s leading universities. A key node in global knowledge networks, NUS will have distinctive expertise and insights relating to Asia.
cons: Every member of our university enjoys diverse opportunities for intellectual, personal and professional growth. Learning and working at NUS will foster quick, well-rounded minds, well-equipped to succeed in our fast-changing world.

pros: Great place to study, one of the top colleges in Singapore and in Asia. Managed to have a global experience during my time here.
cons: Focused too much on studies as opposed to overseas universities where networking had more emphasis. Could be more essential than knowledge.

review_title: Working at NUS as an Research Institute
pros: Good medical coverage, nice colleagues and highly affordable food / housing for staff. Competent colleagues who are able to provide high quality feedback in improving your work.
cons: Restrictive requirements on journal publications. Should allow all major top tier journals to be accepted into consideration for tenure-ship and promotion. More generous research grant would also be appreciated.

pros: I have worked as Summer research intern in NUSNNI - Nanocore, got the opportunity to work with one of the greatest Nanotechnology laboratories in the world. Well Equipped research facilities with cutting edge technology. The main research areas are Oxide Electronics, Nanomaterials.
cons: I haven't faced any difficulties. The real challenge is understanding indepth research and compete with it.

pros: Good place to work in. Nice People to work with.Beautiful campus. Encouraging supervisor. Supportive coworkers. Feel great to work with professors and students. Good but cheap food.
cons: Not much to me. Health insurance for the research staff can be better. there was no bonus available at the end of year. No clear career path. difficult to be promoted.

Bureaucracy. There is a lot of administrative things going on.
Salary is not very competitive, though it is not a primary factor for me.

review_title: Great place to work and especially learn, to improve oneself.
pros:
- Flexible working hours.
- Excellent medical benefits with clinics and hospital nearby.
- Really cheap good food and drinks compared to off-campus.
- Great place for learning for self-improvement.
- Vibrant world-class R&D community.
cons:
- Salary increment is negligible.
- No bonus.
- Hurdles of bureaucracy.

pros: You will know a lot about technical stuffs. If you are planning do go to graduate school and work on research then this is an option
cons: The salaries are not that competitive as compared to industrial companies. Sometimes the research can be boring and you don't have many partners to work with

review_title: Nurturing environment where you are encouraged to actively upgrade yourself all the time
pros: You get to learn from some of the best in the field and work with them directly.  Valuable resources are available at your disposal.
cons: Tend to become out of touch with sectors beyond your scope and as a result fall back without realising.

pros: NUS is a Well funded university. International collaborations. Good recreational facilites. Cheap and good food on-campus. Multicultural and multi - ethinic.
cons: NUS has relatively small campus. And for some odd reasons theres always construction hapening in some part of the campus which is makes it a bit noisy and dusty.

review_title: Good place for work life balance
pros:
Flexible timing as long as you get your planned work done.
Perfect for working mother with one or more young kids.
Various staff benefit such as health, curriculum
cons:
Lack of challenge. Can foresee the ceiling of your career if stay in the same position.
Contract-based, renewal of contract solely dependent on Professor's grant.

pros: Great professors and great research environment. All kinds of advanced experimental equipment at hands. All staffs are highly professional.
cons: NUS itself is always the best, but still, the campus is a little too small, and weather of Singapore never changes. And, Singlish can be really hard to understand sometimes.

pros: The Institute values workplace safety and takes good care of its employees with the help of the human resource department. It is currently one of the best university in the world and it was a pleasure to start my career there
cons: Too many steps to follow to get a job done

pros: Really good working environment for fresh graduates with colleagues of your age. A bridge between school and industry where staff could be better prepared for professional service and career in the future. Good work-life balance with more-than-average annual leaves.
cons: Non-academic staff have really limited pathways. Salary is not competitive with the industry.

pros: The university has very beautiful views and convenient transportations. All colleagues are quite supportive. Besides, got cheap food at the canteens. Good stuff wellfare.
cons: The salary is not that competitive. The work pace is slower .

pros: learned new knowledge in the working lab. very good working office........really.
cons: high workload. there is no work life balance for some of my colleague.really annoying.

review_title: A good place to work at...
pros:
- Great place to work at, with good colleagues.
- Good and cheap food around.
- Good benefits and annual leave.
cons:
- Can be a very stagnant career.
- Very easily got into a comfort zone which people don't feel like to move on.
- Not very accessible.

review_title: One of the best universities in Asia
pros: Very good facilities, new and modern extensive collection of books in libraries. if fully used, can be very helpful in developing one's knowledge and experience

pros: NUS is a great place to work. The campus view is nice. I was given freedom to explore my ideas in research which I found really appealing.

Payment was not high, but reasonable.
Overall life at Singapore can become a bit monotonous, just like the hot and wet weather there.

pros:
Very efficient in arrangement of TEP

Work-Life Balance
Interesting work

cons:

pros: Good working environment, great staff and facilities, efficient admin support
cons: Salary is low, especially for foreign students.  Coursework load for phd's is relatively high compared to other international institutions of the same league

pros: I have been working there three years. The working environment is competitive but excellent. There are great colleagues who are willing to help and share everything. Facilities are good and acceptable salary.
cons: No bonus, pressure for publication, and work-life balance have really depended on the PIs.

pros: very good place to study and live. should be a good place to start a career if you would like to do research
cons: not very much. The diversity is not very high. You cannot expect the tier 1 level of research and people here

pros: Good environment and funding. Nice colleagues and easy to fit in. The salary is fair enough to live in Singapore and better than US schools.

review_title: NUS is an open, helpful environment

Challenging work scope
Not so busy so can get work-life balanced
Rich environment to know many more things
cons: Not always using industrial standard design, so you might not be able to catch up with industry if you decided to quit

pros: people are nice and a lot of paid leaves. colleagues are friendly and helpful.
cons: varied regulations and culture between different department and institutes.

pros:
Supportive colleagues
Generous benefits (e.g. paid leave)
Flexible work environment

Working in a large university can be very bureaucratic — certain processes can be arduous when they needn’t be

review_title: I was a research assistant for a study abroad program
pros: Absolutely gorgeous campus, plenty of things to do in Singapore, and the food is both cheap and amazing

pros: It is a great place to work. I was given freedom to explore my ideas which I found really appealing.

review_title: It is a very good place for starting academically.

pros: good equipment facilities, good environment, strong research faculty and lab group... Enjoyed the 4 year Ph.D years here

pros: You may meet many international employees, little Singaporeans

pros: soc department has strong database, multimedia groups.

pros: it is a lot of freedom to do what you like at work.

review_title: NUS offers Good progression and a challenging environment for young individuals to strive in

job_title: Graduate Student in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros:
Diversity.
Too much fund.
They have some awesome international faculty especially the young.
cons:
Too harsh treatment for international students from developing countries especially from local professors.

review_title: An organisation about growth and learning

pros: Excellent staff and students and campus environment!

pros: great place to work and grow.
